Thank you for explaining how and why you make videos! It would be nice to see some home-made science demonstrations with everyday household things and substances (fun for kids and parents... and anyone who enjoys science really!)
I like the way a narrow linear flow of water from a tap can be bent by putting a statically charged biro near it. Or how a helium balloon can 'pretend to be in zero-G' when it has lost enough helium to be the same buoyancy as the air (I had fun videoing this as I was trying to spin it like a flying saucer but it wanted to be vertical not horizontal!) Or how big a bubble you can blow... I tried blowing hemispherical bubbles on my desk -they grew quite big like a foot or more in diameter. There must be loads of fun sort-of scientific things you can do at home.

Just a thought.  My students learn the words of particle theory, but don't really grok it.  They keep thinking kinetic energy causes motion, not that KE is motion.  They think temperature speeds up particle motion, rather than being a measure of it.  They think temperature causes pressure, rather than it just being a measure of particle speed.  They don't see pressure as the pelting of particles.  Temperature and Pressure were measured before the existence of atoms was widely accepted.  (1905 Einstein)

I must tell you about a hologram exhibit I saw in Seattle Washington many, many years ago.
The exhibit was irradiated via laser light and the particular display which interested me most was a wall hanging that depicted a night sky theme.
There were stars, many stars, and from the lower corner was a telescope pointing into the heavens above. It appeared to be a moonless night. The telescope actually appeared to extend beyond the frame, and out of the front of the picture, possible to a distance of several inches.
Of course, I passed my hand through the image of the telescope to show my children that it was only an image and not a real telescope as it did appear to be.
So, here’s this telescope protruding out of the front of the picture of a star filled sky, and in my opinion, begging to be looked through.
So I did. And what to my surprise there, as clear as a bell, was the full moon as bright as could be.
My responds was…WOW.
If you can find that hologram, it just might be something your viewers would be interested in. I know I was.
And thank you for all the information you present on this YouTube channel.

In Regards to the true light speed measurement. Please review.

Two Clocks at a Distance from one another, One Laser in Center at Triangle position. Mirror Splitter sends Laser Light which Activates Digital Clocks, wich are wired back to the triangle center position. One high speed camera focused on both Clock monitors.

Now block the left Laser reflection.

Send light to the Right Clock.

Right Clock reflects to a mirror back to the Center.

Fron Center, Light reflects to the Left side.

Left Side reflects straight to the Right Side, Stoping Right Clock on Arrival.

Right Side Mirror reflects Laser back, straight to Left side Stoping Left Clock.

By now you should have a clear Measurement.

1) I am fascinated by what I cannot see. What are nebula like in outer space? Are they hot? Could I survive in a space suit? I think I know the answers but it would be fun to explore how awful life off our planet would be and it would underscore how important taking our environment seriously is.

Yo @Veritasium, I got a solution to the measuring speed of light in one direction.
Lets say I have an object that can move at really fast speeds. The name of the object is A. If I can launch A at a speed that's close to the speed of light, than I could possibly measure the speed of light.

If I can launch a light beam and A at the same time and I have a timer that starts when one of the two reaches the end of a specific distance and stops when the other reaches the end, then we could measure the speed of light in one direction. We would have the speed of A. If we take that speed and use it to find the time of launch, adding that to the time on the timer, which is the difference in time between when the objects arrived at the ending point, you would have the speed of light.
Thank you!!

As a new viewer, I enjoy most the Veritasium videos in which you apply your deep sense of curiosity and wonder to the deepest roots of how the natural universe is structured. A higher degree in science tempts many folks to use that knowledge to impress others. You have chosen the harder path of trying to lay bare, to anyone interested, the mysteries that may still lie buried beneath the maths. In doing so, you suggest that our understanding may not be as deep as our mathematical precision suggests. That is a good thing since any science that loses its sense of mystery becomes an elaborate form of engineering. Science must be more than just the application of what is known. It must, at its heart, remain the search for what is not known.

BTW, in the speed-of-light measurement video, if you synchronized two cesium clocks midway between points A and B, in the experiment, and then physically moved the clocks at low relativistic speeds to points A and B (in a consistent way), you could do one-way light measurements, from A to B and B to A, that could show how close the measurements agree, to a high degree of accuracy. To account for the earth's rotation, the sun's path in the galaxy, and the galaxies' journey through space, you should repeat the experiment in as many directions as you can manage (even up and down). My guess, is that all measurements will agree to better than 99%.

re: your question to us, I would love to hear more about social dimensions and issues within the scientific community: the general concepts of peer review (beyond just prepublication review), the replication crisis, the publication cycl/industry and obstacles it creates to scientific research and communication, the economic context of scientific grants/funding and where it works well and poorly (vaccine funding could be a great topic within this, given the current news on COVID-19 vaccines and how quickly they were trialled and approved), publish-or-perish, PhD supply vs. demand and where PhDs go when they don't become professors or researchers at private research institutes/labs in their field, etc.

Some other topics like scientific journalism and public science communication could also be really fascinating (e.g. common question I hear/address, why do we always hear about new cures for cancer being discovered but cancer never seems cured?).

I know you've covered p-hacking in the past (hey, that's how I discovered your channel!), not sure if you have touched other topics like this - also not sure if these more humanities/social studies topics would catch your interest compared to hard science topics like the general relativity and pure maths stuff you've done recently. If it does catch your interest, would love to hear your takes on them, though, especially since you already have some personal experience with this world through your PhD.

(Also: Hey! I never realised you were Canadian. =3 )

Veritasium and Vsauce combined are literally the reason I became so fascinated by science in the first place. Vsauce was like an unintimidating door into science, while Veritasium is what gave depth after having opened that door.

I find regularly (e.g. also with Kurzgesagt), that dabbling in relativity and parallel universes and supernovas and carbon nano-tubes is nice, but .... there is nothing more powerful than taking the most mundane thing and learning something new about it. I know thats really hard to do, so I am not sure you can use this as a direction to explore more (or that you even want to), but if you could take something simple like your very oldest topics like "What causes the seasons?" and apply your current mindset to it ... find something new and interesting about them, I think that would be great.

Hello Mr Veritasium,
To answer your question as to what we or in this case I would like to see more of, I would like to tell you a small story.
As part of my morning routine I was browsing the news (BBC if you are interested), more specific on October the 16 in the year 2017. On this morning I saw the headline "Einstein's waves detected in star smash", at first glance it was interesting for sure, but at first that’s all I left it at. However a short while after, you released a video on this subject and after watching it, I gave the original article a second glance and read it and finished it with a feeling of confusement but curiosity, this curiosity quickly developed into a fascination for astronomy.
So first of all, thank you for all the work you and your team put in, and to answer your question; I would love to see videos perhaps highlighting any amazing or off the radar discoveries or results of someone’s research (maybe once a month?). This idea of mine stems from the want to know about current/new discoveries in the world of STEM
Of course this just an idea and if deemed too much, well it is what it is :).

Congrats on the 10 years Derek. I have totally loved your work along the journey. It was amazing meeting you at the 2012 Physics Teachers Conference in Melbourne Australia (all thoughts years ago). I couldn't believe you were born in Traralgon, where I teach. I was over the moon when you did a video conference for the Physics kids for the secondary school at which I teach. It was the highlight of the school year for myself and many of my students. Such an engaging, positive and inspirational role model for scientist enthusiasts, students and teachers. I have nothing but admiration and praise for the amazing work you do, Kind regards. Mark.

Hey, I posited a solution to proving lightspeed isn't one way and no responded. Just look at the CMB. It's the same in all directions. If lightspeed had directionality we would see different universe states depending on which direction we look. One direction we would see the CMB as that is what the universe was ~13.4B years ago, and another we would see the universe in real time extending to infinity. Since we don't see a different distance, either further or closer, in any direction we can surmise lightspeed is truly the same in all directions.

For me something really interesting is what Neodimiun strong permanent magnets can do, like this trhree examples:
* If one magnet is rotating at the correct speed and orientation it can trap in place another magnet, similar to what type two superconductors can do.
* Five magnets with a very specific orientation, in bottom of three or more 'legs' of a 'table', when such magnets are rotating over a conductor plate they can levitate the 'table' and a lot of weigth over it (>100kg).
* Fast acceleration and high speed appears, so high speed that magnet can scape the system, when two bar magnets that are touching each other (by their own magnetic attraction) are placed in a path, inside a transparent tube so they do not hit anything, when at both sides there are similar bar magnets all in parallel and all in repulsion to each other, like this schematic chart:
NNNNNNNNN <--- (1)
SSSSSSSSSSS <--- (1)
- - - - - - - - <--- (2)
NSNS <--- (3)
- - - - - - - - <--- (2)
SSSSSSSSSSS <--- (1)
NNNNNNNNN <--- (1)
Where (1) are identical bar magnets as in (3) but with ortogonal orientatios to (3) ones, (2) are the walls that avoid magnets (3) to hit magnets (1).
That construction creates motion by it self, the point of equilibrium is to stay in motion at a really high speed, till magnets (3) scape the system, they go out with so much speed that they move away more than one meter (tested with Supermag toy over a plastic plate), tube is made of a non magnetic, non paramagnetic material, like transparent plastic.
All that and a lot more weird things that can be done with really strong neodimiun magnets, that not much people really investigate seriously and less people show experimentically.

Make a video about Climate Change. But instead of looking for the evidence that supports your preconceived beliefs – which is how pseudoscience works – do it scientifically. Look at all the evidence and see where it leads. In the video, you should answer the following questions:
1. What exactly is Climate Change? Because, we already know we're in the middle of an interglacial period aka a global warming. So... climate is changing... how exactly? Is an ice age coming sooner than expected? Or will the global warming intensify?
2. How can we distinguish between natural climate change and man made climate change?
3. Is there sufficient evidence to believe human activity causes Climate Change?
4. If humans cause climate change, how do we know that we're not accidentally stabilizing it? How do we know, for example, that a naturally occurring ice age is coming and, thanks to our industrial activity, we're delaying that ice age?
5. How do we know that the measures you propose won't actually make matters worse. It's a chaotic system after all!

Oh, I almost forgot. While you talk about the climate, don't forget to make the viewers understand what a chaotic system is. And make sure they understand that in science, chaotic means, by definition, unpredictable. I mean, it order to predict such a system, you would have to break the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle.

10 REASONS THAT MAKE ME DOUBT HUMANS CAUSE CLIMATE CHANGE

① Throughout most of its history Earth had no polar ice caps and the average global temperature was between 8°C and 15°C warmer than present time.

② We are in the middle of a 2.58-million-year-old glaciation – the Quaternary Glaciation.

③ The current global warming started about 12,000 years ago. That's how the last ice age ended and the current interglacial period, the Holocene, began. This warm and cozy climate won't last forever – interglacial periods last between 20,000 and 60,000 years.

④ Between 12,000 and 7,000 years ago the sea level rose by 197 ft (60 m). Look up the Early Holocene Sea Level Rise!

⑤ The climate is always changing. There is no such thing as a stable climate. If you want to learn more about the stability of the climate, you might want to look up: The 8.2 Kiloyear Event; The Little Ice Age; The Year Without a Summer (1816).

⑥ Compared to solar activity, the Milankovitch Cycles or volcanic activity, human activity has an insignificant effect in the long term evolution of the climate. We cannot start, end, or prevent ice ages or global warmings. We're not that significant.

⑦ Chaos Theory explains how the behavior of some systems is unpredictable (chaotic). Even simple systems can exhibit chaotic behavior, like the double pendulum (look it up!). No one can predict the climate, because the climate is a stupidly complex chaotic system.

⑧ During the Hirnantian glaciation there was 10 times more atmospheric CO₂.

⑨ 95% of all greenhouse gases on earth is water vapor.

⑩ CO₂ does not fit in any way shape or form the definition of a pollutant. Almost all the oxygen in the atmosphere is a byproduct of photosynthesis – a process by which plants use light energy to produce glucose from CO₂ and water. CO₂ is used in the food industry, for example, in the production of carbonated beverages like: beer, soda, sparkling water etc. CO₂ is also used in hospitals, for example, in laparoscopic surgery.


There are many scientists who disagree with various aspects of the man-made climate change hypothesis. One of them is Ivar Giaever, Nobel laureate in physics, who said that "Global Warming is pseudoscience". Freeman Dyson said that "Climate Change predictions are absurd". Keep in mind that science doesn't work by consensus. Science isn't a democracy. As Carl Sagan put it:

Science is more than a body of knowledge. It is a way of thinking; a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility. If we are not able to ask skeptical questions, to interrogate those who tell us that something is true, to be skeptical of those in authority, then, we are up for grabs for the next charlatan (political or religious) who comes rambling along.

In general, when you're convinced of your truth, make an effort to get out of the echo chamber and listen to the opposite point of view. You might learn something.

As far as what I’d like to see in 2021, it’s complicated. It looks like your interests range across multiple scientific disciplines and the way of thinking necessary for science to flourish. I certainly appreciate that interdisciplinary approach to understanding how the world works. But what really attracts me to this channel is the challenging of intuitions and easily unquestionable assumptions and elucidation upon how the process of science is done. I’d love to see a lot of that in 2021, especially the elucidation upon how science is done. I watched your video about the illusion only some can see and saw a connection to the video you made about confirmation, and both of those videos were certainly interesting. But I want to know how science applies the Raven Paradox and falsifiability to theories. Also, your video about the two-way speed of light was incredible. I’d love to see more videos challenging deeply held assumptions in most people that are really just conventions. I will research this on my own, but I think that making videos on this will be useful for everybody.

As a freshman in college hoping to become a theoretical physicist, I’m interested in not only the philosophy of science but also challenging my own intuitions and thinking. This could be because I have a high need for cognition that frequently overshadows the pleasantness of cognitive ease. Also, I’ve learned skepticism and inquisitiveness (bit through the education system, but through many of things, including watching your videos).

As for future direction, a thought that may appeal to you: One of my favorite books is Kathryn Schulz's "Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error", and a fair bit of your work leans into the idea of what you would expect and how it might differ from the facts (e.g., street interviews, optical illusions, and so on). Maybe dig more into the idea of how we react to being mistaken, how science is a system designed to keep us from being certain too quickly, how it works to prevent us from staying wrong if we are. Perhaps (?) this is less a topic for some episodes but more of a theme or sub-current of them.
I want to see more educational videos about science stuff that most people get wrong.

Answer to your final question: videos released more often, some of them perhaps with a shorter format. It doesn't have to be that often and that short as Tom Scott for example, but your content is really valuable, but I feel it should appear more often. Maybe think of some series? Either interesting facts about science (for example, 5-10 videos, each a few minute long, with a short history and meaning of the most important discoveries, etc) or maybe a course / training (again, a few videos, explaining some interesting topis, e.g. "understanding special relativity" (general involves to much math, special should be easy enough) or educational series explaining common misconceptions in science - that would be very useful, to have good videos to show to people, so they can understand that radiation doesn't make you glow, how RF impact biological matter (relevant for those 5G conspiracies) or vaccination works (or some else misconceptions, if you prefer to avoid controversial topics).

The Veritasium videos I enjoy most are those that give an introduction to a less well known topic of physics (in pop science), like those on chaos theory and the one on turbulence. One topic I would have in mind is 'Emergence in statistical physics'. Another in the same realm might be 'Universality in phase transitions' or maybe just the Ising model. I feel like statistical physics has not been covered much by the science part of youtube (space things are more popular I guess), while it is a fairly fundamental idea in modern physics.
As a physics master student that focuses on condensed matter, a video on band theory and semi conductor physics could be cool. The idea of electrons in a period potential turning out to be wave-like should be something that is possible to explain to your audience that have heard a few tidbits of Quantum Mechanics over the years. Band filling is a somewhat intuitive concept and could be mind blowing for some as a more fundamental explanation of why some things conduct while other materials don't.
I would also love for you to do a video explaining superconductivity, but I think it would be hard to go beyond the general 'it's two electrons teaming up'. Maybe a video about Bose-Einstein condensates could be more accessible, with the Helium condensate fountain as a cool hook.

I think you also like to sometimes illuminate little known things about big topics in pop science. Your two-way speed of light video would be an example of that.
A topic I would like to see you cover is fundamentals of Probability, Randomness and Determinism, although you have covered it loosely in videos like the Quantum Entanglement one.
Sean Carroll did an excellent lecture series over the summer. You might find inspiration in the episode 19 (Probability and Randomness). One very cool little thing he mentioned is that Classical Mechanics is in fact not deterministic either and he gives a very specific example (Norton's Dome).

I hope some of these ideas give you inspiration.

Probably my favorite video over your body of work was actually over on the second channel - How Scientists Reacted to Gravitational Wave Detection. That was one of the best insights I've seen into how scientific discovery actually works in the modern era. Yeah, as someone that watches like half the science channels on YouTube I knew 'on paper' how much of modern experimentation is driven by teasing out sigma-level statistical trends from billions of lines of data, no big Eureka moments... but watching an actual researcher walk through the process on such a significant project was wholly different than knowing the theory.

That particular type of behind-the-scenes isn't something we get to see very often in the context of the sciences. Lots of other fields have their documentaries and directors commentaries and such that cover these kinds of "how the sausage is made" moments but it's pretty rare outside of the entertainment industry, from what I've run across anyway. If I was going to actively ask for something specific from the channel, that would be it - more talks with scientists/researchers/etc. about how they came to accept some particular piece of data as legitimate or change their minds about some theory.

( Of course, it didn't hurt any that the other LIGO videos are also among the best of the channel and experiment itself is bloody awe inspiring. )

Regarding the laptop give-away:
I hope you did more than just press the delete button to delete files off your old computer. That would only change entries in your file allocation table. The files are still there, but just do not have an entry in the F.A.T. anymore. So i would recommend a file deletion that ensure that un-delete or file recovery do not potentially expose possible private files to anyone you don't want them to have.

For me Veritasium was what kept my connection to science after school. When I graduated and was thinking on what to do for college, I wanted physics, biology or astronomy, but my parents kept telling me that in Brazil I would be poor studying those, my future was going to be a poor teacher; I was insecure, so I heard them, and I chose Architecture.
